lines.text: Why did my father kill himself?
I don't know, son.
Tell me! Tell me!
A long time ago, a man was killed... shot in the back.
My father did it?
Nobody knew for sure who did it.
You knew. Why didn't he hang?
There was nothing to be gained by hanging. The dead man had a child - a son. Your father agreed to raise him as his own.
[Mr. Brant, the undertaker, tries to console Mrs. Mills, the "grieving" widow]
Needless to say, Mrs. Mills, we all share your grief.
What's the price of your cheapest funeral?

They said it's only right and proper that I should give Luke a good Christian funeral. Fill him with formaldehyde and plaster down his hair so good Christian folk can come look at him on display like at a wax museum.
It's awful seeing a man kill himself. One minute he's there... alive... then he's dead. Blood and the smell of powdersmoke. And it's all over and done with. It's awful!
Civilization is a wonderful thing, ain't it, Doc?
If they ever got it started it might work.
You mean that, didn't you?
Mean what?
About marrying me.
Yeah.
When, Frank?
Right now.
Can a bride have an hour to get ready?
It'll take you that long?
Uh-huh.
Well, all right, but hurry up.
Frank?
Yeah?
What about the preacher? He might want to be in on this.
Do you want to know something, Dan?
What?
You're a bad liar. If you want to succeed in this world, you got to learn to be a good liar.

We don't have any law in this jerkwater town - he's the law! He's passed his sentence on practically everything and everyone. The people should be the law and will be the law, when they get the urge to get rid of Frank Patch. You see, gentlemen, what we're really deciding here is whether we move forward or backward. We either need to keep up with the times or we lose out.
[discussing Frank Patch]

There's that mayor over there drumming up a meeting with all those rich and proper jackasses - hollering and shouting around, quoting some stupid law or bylaw. Then they'll all go stomping down to the jailhouse, take a look at God Almighty, then he'll take one good look back at 'em, and they'll all wet their britches and go on home.
I can't charge you for crying on my sheets.
I had too much to drink.
Of course you did, lover.
Take the money.
For what? If a pipefitter can't lay pipe, he ought to try another business.
